Ancient peoples, whether they knew what they were at the time or not, have always had at least 3 of the six simple machines: the lever, pulley, and inclined plane. The other three are forms of the first 3. The wedge is a form of inclined plane. The wheel and axel is part pulley, part lever. And the screw is part inclined plane, being an inclined plane in a circle.
I once saw a demonstration of balancing a heavy rock onto a crosswise beam, placing another beam into the shed (triangular space) created by the leaning rock and lifting that up, and placing more and more beams to get the rock on top. Another television show I saw a long time ago showed a group of people who used an obelisk such as the Ancient Egyptians created who set up the heavy obelisk by creating a hole for the obelisk to be placed in, and one side was graded at a diagonal so it could be dragged down by rope tackle to the placement point. I think a key point about carbon dating that not everyone understands is that the proportion of carbon-14 is continually being replenished in the atmosphere so when plants absorb CO2, that carbon will always be in the same stable proportion of carbon-14 to other carbon isotopes. That means that any animals which eat the plant, or eat whatever ate the plant, will also be continually replenishing carbon-14 via new plant matter. When the organism dies, they stop ingesting new carbon-14 but the carbon-14 they already have continues to decay.

Misinformation alert!!! Nobody thinks they used a frames to erect the stones anymore.   They used dirt ramps and holes.  They pushed the stones up the ramps and let them fall into the holes. But they didn't,  because wood isn't strong enough...

It's sad that so much of human history has been lost to time. Yes, we might know just enough to get a general idea of what took place around specific places and times, but just stop and think for a moment about all of the things that certainly happened around/near Stonehenge. These were human beings, after all, and they were really not all that very different from you and me today with respect to their basic biological makeup including everything that that entails. People met and had romantic affairs (while, yes, they were certainly not exactly like today's relationships, the basic fundamental emotions they would have felt would still be very familiar to you and me today); political escapades and fiascos would have abounded around such an important site; small wars replete with triumphant victories and agonizing defeats ran their course; extended families met in joyful gatherings/feasts and they most certainly had their fair share of awkward moments complete with weird family members being snickered at (or feared/loathed). And many many more wonderful as well as awful events and occurrences almost without count all took place with many many humans involved; all experiencing joy and sadness, laughter and rage, perplexity and enlightenment, and every other singular emotion, both simple and complex, that each and every one of us feels today.

However, virtually all of these stories have been lost to the winds and sands of staggeringly ponderous time. And all we have left of that Himalayan dwarfing mountain of human emotions is a few cold grey silent monoliths planted in the earth, and even they will eventually and most certainly disappear at some point in the (hopefully) very very distant future. So, if someday you ever somehow find yourself visiting such a place, slowly and solemnly approach one of those massive megalithic stones, place your hands upon it, look up to its top where it meets the sky, and then slowly close your eyes and listen to the wind. Try to see if you can imagine or even feel the lives and emotions of all those many many many people, people who you almost certainly share genetic material with*. Honor their lost stories, both minor and epic, by thinking about where we've been together as a species and where we're headed. What kind of millennial project could we aspire to build which would instill awe and wonder in the humans of the far future? And also try to think about how you yourself would want to be remembered by someone thousands of years from now. Maybe if more people thought in that way, especially with the aid of literal touchstones, it would help to insure a positive future for all humanity; both reminding and instilling in us the fact that we are all in this together and that by working together we can almost certainly tip the oh so very tenuous balance of success and failure in our favor. Long may Stonehenge remain. :) Take care, everyone! :)

*I read somewhere that you only have to go back about 2 or 3 thousand years in your family tree to find an ancestor who is common to every other human alive today. I forget the exact number of years, but in fact, it might even be a shorter amount of time. :)

Fun fact: by the system archaeologists now use to classify these monuments, Stonehenge isn't a henge. A henge consists of a circular bank with a ditch inside of it. This is how we know they were ceremonial rather than defensive enclosures, since if it were defensive the bank would be on outside. Stonehenge's ditch is on the outside of the bank. So, but for the awkward fact that we get the word "henge" itself from Stonehenge, it wouldn't be considered a henge monument at all.

An interesting note - I read a book in which someone was investigating the notion that Stonehenge may have had a counterpart, during the time when it was "in use" as it were...Woodhenge. They've found a site somewhat near to Stonehenge, with almost the same layout, but with evidence that wooden structures were set up there, not stone ones. The researchers thought maybe that Stonehenge was for the dead, but Woodhenge was for the living; and that maybe people traveled from far away to these two henges as a yearly event - perhaps as a kind of tribal reunion? It seems that the wooden henge might have seen use for ceremonies and rites - maybe marriages, or inter-clan negotiations, the kind of thing that ends feuds and seals alliances. Or, maybe it was more like the ancient Norse "Althing" - a large meeting of chieftains where laws could be debated and various legal disputes settled. This was all quite a while ago, but I was fascinated by the idea. After all, the Egyptians and other ancient cultures certainly had various yearly events, both religious and not; it makes sense that wandering tribes might also need to meet at some regular point in time, to keep touch, or to trade, or to make marriage matches between clans.

https://www.amazon.com/Stonehenge-Understanding-Mysteries-Greatest-Monument/dp/1615191933

That's the book; this link shows the reprint from 2014, but I read it in the first printing. :)

It still amazes me that scientists refuse to consider that the people who built these things had wheels. Just because wheels don't show up in archeological record till much later, does not mean they didn't exist. Wheels of that time were most likely wood. If a wheel broke and couldn't be repaired, they're not just going to throw it away when they can salvage it for perfectly good firewood to cook a meal with, or use it to keep you warm at night. Everyone knows that wood in a damp or wet environment will break down fairly quickly, and England is renowned for fog and rain, so a wooden wheel wouldnt last long enough for people of our time to find it. Humans were smart, even back then. It's not really a stretch to consider that these people were bright enough to invent the wheel out of necessity. As the old saying goes, "Necessity is the mother of invention".

As for building, let’s think archeology practices here. Build a mound, pull the stones in, level them as you say, then pull the lintels on top without any lifting whatsoever, then when everything is in place, dig away the soil and you have something that looked like it was constructed, rather than purely just putting stones in holes and topping them off at ground level with no lifting. They will do an awful lot to make this happen.

This is human nature, and we have MANY, MANY EXAMPLES of this behavior occurring throughout human history. You could even do it today, and we often do. The government can't repair significant stretches of road in less then a year, while a given megachurch can fund and erect incredible churches in far less time, and those guys don't even promise a good harvest or significant monetary wealth to their followers. We put a man on the moon using technology that frankly shouldn't have brought those guys back in one piece. We have populated an entire dead planet with robots for no reason that an archaeologist will ever be able to decipher.
